items.title: 'Understand that anger': Jewish community grapples with massacre
items.description: As Sydney marks one week since the antisemitic Bondi attack, the Jewish community is grappling with the question of where to go from here.

items.title: Live: Circle of peace forms at Bondi as Day of Reflection begins
items.description: A National Day of Reflection is being held, as people across the country are invited to light a candle at 6:47pm, one week since the attack. Follow Live.

items.title: Right now, it's OK to be quiet. The quieter you become, the more you hear
items.description: If we are to inch towards unity, the more we pause to listen, the more sure-footed our path forward will be.

items.title: 'Another level of betrayal': Survivors search the Epstein files to find nothing
items.description: Despite giving an FBI interview and victim statement, Epstein victim Jess Michaels finds no trace of her evidence in the vast trove published online.

items.title: Images removed from Epstein files less than a day after being posted
items.description: At least 16 Jeffrey Epstein-related files, including a photo of President Donald Trump, have disappeared from a US Department of Justice webpage within a day of being posted, with no explanation.

items.title: Who's named in the Epstein files and who else was he connected to?
items.description: The Epstein files offer another glimpse into the financier's vast network of wealthy and influential figures. Here's what we know about his relationships with some of the world's most powerful people.

items.title: Live: Australia on cusp of Ashes victory on day five at the Adelaide Oval
items.description: Australia begins the final day of the third Ashes Test with series victory in sight, with England in need of a miracle to avoid going 3-0 down at the Adelaide Oval. Follow live.

items.title: Retirement dreams shattered after paying $84k for a never-built house
items.description: Multiple people are speaking out about their experience paying too much to a building company for work never delivered.

items.title: 'I didn't agree to it': Rise of automatic tipping sparks backlash
items.description: Australia’s tipping culture is in the spotlight, following reports more businesses are adding automatic tips to diners’ bills in response to rising operating costs.

items.title: An algorithm said Lina would be safe. Then she was murdered
items.description: In Spain, police have developed technology to work out how at-risk women might be from domestic violence. Some people have grave concerns about how often the algorithm is wrong.

items.title: Paul calls out star boxer despite suffering double broken jaw in defeat
items.description: Jake Paul calls out Canelo Alvarez as the American recovers from a double broken jaw from his controversial fight with Anthony Joshua.

items.title: This is how a Richmond bowls club became a haven for LGBTQI+ inclusion
items.description: Three years ago, Richmond became the first lawn bowls club in the world to hold a Pride Cup. Since then, it has attracted a community of queer people who were otherwise lost to sport.

items.title: Movie animation technology can help athletes recover from ACL injuries
items.description: The reasons for high rates of serious knee injuries among female athletes are not fully understood.

items.title: The fight to save Australia's disappearing beaches
items.description: Most Australians live by the beach, but the coastline we have built our lives around is disappearing before our eyes.

items.title: How a silly, satirical K-pop hit forever shaped our cultural landscape
items.description: Who'd have guessed a South Korean man doing a goofy horse dance was a recipe for a global phenomenon? Thirteen years after it made YouTube history we revisit the legacy of Psy's Gangnam Style.

items.title: The women who gave up their art to make Arthur Boyd a celebrated artist
items.description: A new exhibition highlights the women behind acclaimed Australian mid-century artist Arthur Boyd, bringing their overlooked stories and art practices to the fore.

items.title: Song, hugs and devotion help workers thrive 2,000km from home
items.description: Moving to another country to provide for your family is not an easy choice but singing, hugs and faith make it easier for these Pacific island workers.

items.title: 'Nearly zero' chance: How a community kept its tai chi teacher
items.description: Jack Yang's immigration lawyer said his chances of staying in Australia were "nearly zero," but Ballarat's tai chi community had other plans.

items.title: Mail sorting on vacant block leaves residents getting bills weeks late
items.description: Residents of a popular north Queensland suburb say they are receiving bills and overdue notices on the same day.

items.title: 'Dead zones' prompt tour operator to fund marine study
items.description: For more than two decades, Rob Pennicott has taken tourists to see the D'Entrecasteaux Channel. But what he describes as "dead zones" have him so worried that he is funding a study to find what is going wrong.

items.title: Outback bike program celebrates four years of teaching the next generation
items.description: An Alice Springs teenager who grew up with cycling program Bikes Mwerre is now sharing his knowledge with the next generation. It's a full-circle moment for the outback program built on pride, skills and belonging.

items.title: Early Christmas gift for recreational fishers as some restrictions ease
items.description: Some recreational fishing restrictions initially put in place to protect fish stocks impacted by South Australia's algal bloom have now been eased.

items.title: Aussie firms as Olympics favourite with another monobob victory
items.description: Australia's Bree Walker claims back-to-back World Cup wins to firm as the monobob favourite heading into the Winter Olympics.

items.title: Residents on mining grids not afforded same discounts as rest of WA
items.description: Residents in small Pilbara towns with power grids run by mining companies are excluded from home battery rebate schemes.

items.title: After a million kilometres, stock agent retires LandCruiser 4WD
items.description: A Victorian stock agent's four-wheel drive LandCruiser has reached a rare milestone, as experts say Australians are keeping their cars longer than ever.
